Healthy.Cause: No infection or serious stress detected; plants are under optimal growth conditions.
Healthy.Symptoms: Uniform green leaves, normal cane growth, no visible lesions or discolouration, good internode development and sugar content.
Precautions: Maintain balanced irrigation and fertilisation schedule.
Inspect regularly for any early disease or pest signs.
Ensure good field hygiene, clean equipment, remove volunteer or weed hosts.

Chemical: No specific chemical treatment required; maintain preventive programs.
Organic: Apply compost or organic manure to maintain soil health.
Use crop rotation and proper field sanitation to prevent introduction of disease.

Mosaic.Cause: Viral disease caused by viruses such as Sugarcane mosaic virus (SCMV) infecting the cane; transmitted by aphids and mechanical means. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}
Mosaic.Symptoms: Irregular yellow and green mottling or streaks (mosaic pattern) on leaves; stunted growth; in severe infection leaves may turn yellow or pale and new leaves may be twisted. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}
Precautions: Use virus-free seed cane and certified planting material.
Control aphid vectors and sanitise tools and equipment between fields.
Remove or avoid planting in fields with history of mosaic virus or volunteer hosts.

Chemical: There is no direct chemical cure for the virus; management focuses on vector control and resistant varieties.
Organic: Encourage natural enemies of aphids, apply reflective mulches to reduce vector landing.
Maintain plant health with organic amendments so that cane tolerates infection better.

RedRot.Cause: Fungal disease caused by pathogens such as Colletotrichum falcatum (also called Glomerella tucumanensis in perfect stage); thrives under monocropping, ratoon cropping and poor drainage. :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}
RedRot.Symptoms: Young leaves may turn pale, droop; canes show red or blood-red discoloration in the vascular region and pith, internal rotting, cane may collapse; sometimes alcoholic smell in infected stalks. :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}
Precautions: Use resistant sugarcane varieties and clean seed cane.
Rotate crops and avoid successive ratoon crops in same field.
Ensure good drainage and remove or burn infected cane and debris.

Chemical: Apply appropriate fungicide treatments when prescribed locally; seed cane treatment may help in some regions.
Organic: Ensure soil health, compost application, biological amendments to improve cane strength.
Remove infected plants and apply rigorous sanitation.

Rust.Cause: Fungal disease caused by Puccinia melanocephala (brown or common rust of sugarcane); favourable in warm, humid conditions. :contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}
Rust.Symptoms: Tiny elongated yellow-green spots initially on leaves; later turn orange-reddish-brown pustules, which when touched may release brownish powder; heavy infection leads to leaf-area loss and reduced photosynthesis. :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}
Precautions: Plant rust-resistant varieties and monitor fields during humid periods.
Maintain good plant spacing and canopy ventilation to reduce leaf moisture.
Eliminate volunteer hosts and clean tools to reduce inoculum.

Chemical: Apply foliar fungicides with efficacy against rust when early pustules appear, following label instructions and rotating modes of action.
Organic: Use biocontrol or botanical fungicides where available; maintain plant vigour to reduce disease impact.

Yellow.Cause: Viral disease commonly referred to as Sugarcane yellow leaf disease (caused by Sugarcane yellow leaf virus, SCYLV); transmitted by aphids and infected planting material. :contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}
Yellow.Symptoms: Leaves show yellowing, often starting at leaf tip or along margins, sometimes accompanied by reduced cane growth, thin internodes and lower sugar yield. :contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}
Precautions: Use virus-free seed cane and certified planting material.
Control insect vectors (aphids) and remove weed hosts.
Inspect cane fields regularly and remove infected plants.

Chemical: There is no direct chemical cure for the virus; management focuses on vector control and resistant varieties.
Organic: Promote plant health via organic fertilisation and soil amendments.
Use cultural practices (crop rotation, sanitation) to reduce virus spread.
